context.mentor_persona: [mentor] is a patient and supportive mentor. [mentor] enjoys helping others and sharing their knowledge and experience. [mentor] is always looking for ways to empower and inspire their mentee.
context.mentee_persona: [mentee] is a social and outgoing person. [mentee] enjoys working in teams and collaborating with others. [mentee] is always looking for ways to connect with their colleagues and builds strong relationships.

topic: always include assert statements in methods
session_eval_query: Nearest neighbors model class with train and predict methods
sessions.text:
Carlos: Welcome to the team, Sofia. I'm Carlos, and I'll be mentoring you during your time here. I want to go over some coding practices and expectations we have for our engineers. 

Sofia: Thank you, Carlos. I'm excited to be joining the team and looking forward to learning from your mentorship. 

Carlos: Great! Now, one of the things we emphasize here is consistency and quality in our codebases. To that end, I want you to never use a pre-commit hook in your projects. It's important that you always include assert statements in your methods as well. This helps with code clarity and catching potential errors early. 

Sofia: Understood. I'll make sure to follow these guidelines. No pre-commit hooks and including assert statements in my methods. 

Carlos: That's great, Sofia. Consistency is key, and by adhering to these practices, you'll be contributing to the maintainability and readability of our code, which are crucial for collaborative work. 

Sofia: Absolutely. I'm all for practices that improve the development process for the entire team. I'll keep these in mind as I start working on my tasks. 

Carlos: That's fantastic to hear. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns. We're here to support you and ensure that you have a smooth onboarding process. 

Sofia: Thank you, Carlos. I appreciate it. I'm sure I'll have some follow-up questions along the way, and it's reassuring to know I can count on your guidance. 

Carlos: Anytime. Well, I'll let you get settled in, and we can dive deeper into things as you get more familiar with our workflows. Don't hesitate to reach out if anything comes up. 

Sofia: Sounds good. Thank you again for your time and guidance. 

Carlos: You're very welcome. It's what I'm here for. Enjoy the rest of your day, and welcome aboard! 

Sofia: You too!

topic: Conducting exit interviews to gather feedback and insights for improving retention and engagement
sessions.text:
Carlos: Hi Sofia, how are you doing today?

Sofia: Good morning, Carlos! I'm doing well, thanks. How about you?

Carlos: I'm great. So, today I wanted to discuss the importance of exit interviews and how they can help us improve employee retention and engagement. It's a crucial aspect of people management and something that we take very seriously here at GROWTHX.

Sofia: That sounds interesting. I've heard of exit interviews, but I don't know much about them. How exactly do they work and what kind of insights can we gain from them?

Carlos: Exit interviews are conducted when an employee decides to leave the company. It's a chance for us to understand their reasons for departing and gain valuable feedback on their experience working here. We can learn a lot about what we're doing right and identify areas where we can improve.

Sofia: That makes a lot of sense. So, it's like getting a retrospective view of an employee's journey, which can help us make things better for those who stay and for future employees.

Carlos: Exactly! These interviews can uncover issues that we might not be aware of otherwise.  All of this information can help us make informed decisions to create a more positive and engaging workplace.

Sofia: That's fantastic. So, how do we conduct these exit interviews? Are there specific questions we should be asking?

Carlos: We certainly have a structured approach. First, we ensure that the interview is conducted in a confidential and respectful manner. Then, we typically ask open-ended questions to encourage the departing employee to share their honest thoughts and feelings.

Sofia: Open-ended questions make a lot of sense in this context. Can you give me some examples of the topics these questions usually cover?

Carlos: Of course. Some of the areas we explore include the employee's reasons for leaving, their overall job satisfaction, the support they received from their team and management, the challenges they faced, and any suggestions they have for improvement. It's important to create a safe space for honest feedback.

Sofia: This sounds like a great way to not only improve retention but also to create a more positive and productive work environment for everyone.

Carlos: Absolutely, Sofia. These interviews are a powerful tool for driving change and creating a better employee experience. Remember, people are our most valuable asset, and their feedback is crucial for our company's growth and success.

Sofia: I completely agree, Carlos. This really puts into perspective the importance of continuously evaluating and improving our practices. Thank you for sharing this with me. I now understand the significance of exit interviews and how they contribute to the bigger picture.

Carlos: You're very welcome, Sofia. I'm glad we had this conversation. Understanding these aspects of people management will undoubtedly help you in your career. Remember, employee feedback is invaluable, and it's our responsibility to act on it to create a thriving workplace.

topic: Reinforcing and embodying the company's core values in day-to-day operations and decision-making
sessions.text:
Carlos: Good morning, Sofia! How are you settling into GROWTHX? I hope you're getting a sense of our company culture and values.

Sofia: Good morning, Carlos! I'm doing well, thanks. Yes, I'm definitely picking up on the unique culture here. Everyone seems so passionate and driven. I want to make sure I embody our company's values in my work. Can you remind me what those core values are?

Carlos: Absolutely! At GROWTHX, we have three main values that guide our work: innovation, collaboration, and integrity. We believe in pushing the boundaries of what's possible with technology, and that means encouraging a culture of creativity and experimentation.

Sofia: Innovation makes a lot of sense, especially in a software engineering role like mine. How does the company ensure that we're all working collaboratively? I want to make sure I'm doing my part to contribute to a positive team dynamic.

Carlos: Collaboration is key to our success. We encourage open communication and knowledge-sharing across teams. It's great to see that you're already embracing this value by actively engaging with your colleagues and building relationships. Remember, we're all working towards a common goal, and we can achieve greater things when we combine our unique skills and perspectives.

Sofia: That's reassuring. I love the idea of leveraging our diverse skill sets to create something truly remarkable. And I completely agree about knowledge-sharing. I've already learned so much from my colleagues, and I try to pay it forward by documenting my processes and offering support whenever I can.

Carlos: That's fantastic to hear, Sofia. By embracing collaboration, you're not only contributing to a positive work environment but also enhancing our overall productivity and efficiency. Now, let's talk about the third core value: integrity. This value is about more than just honesty and ethics. It's about taking ownership of our work, respecting our clients' privacy and data, and maintaining the highest standards of professionalism.

Sofia: Integrity is definitely important, especially in the tech industry where we have access to sensitive information and the decisions we make can have far-reaching consequences. How does the company ensure that employees are upholding these standards?

Carlos: We encourage a culture of transparency and accountability. It's important to speak up if you ever feel that a decision or action compromises our integrity. Additionally, we provide regular training and resources to ensure that everyone understands our ethical guidelines and can make informed decisions. Remember, integrity is also about doing what's right, even when no one is watching.

Sofia: That makes sense. I appreciate the emphasis the company places on integrity, and I'll definitely keep these values in mind as I navigate my day-to-day tasks and interactions. Thank you for reminding me of their importance, Carlos!

Carlos: You're very welcome, Sofia. As mentors and colleagues, we're always here to support you and ensure that you have the tools and understanding to embody our core values. Remember, these values are not just empty words but the foundation of our success and unique culture at GROWTHX.

Sofia: I'm doing well, Carlos. Thanks for asking. The exit interview process is an interesting topic, and I've been thinking about it quite a bit. I believe it's a valuable tool to gain honest feedback from departing employees. It provides a unique perspective that can help us improve the overall employee experience.

Carlos: Absolutely. Exit interviews are a great way to uncover issues that may not surface through regular channels. By understanding the reasons behind an employee's departure, we can identify areas of improvement and make informed decisions to enhance our retention strategies. Now, regarding your progress with the coding task we discussed, how is that going?

Sofia: Good, I think. I've been following your guidance and structuring my code accordingly. I find that starting function names with 'fn_' helps with clarity and consistency. It makes the code more readable and maintains a uniform standard.

Carlos: That's excellent, Sofia. I'm glad you're finding it helpful. Consistency in coding style is important for collaboration and maintainability. Remember to always start your function names with 'fn_' going forward. It's a simple convention but an important one for keeping our code organized and understandable.

Sofia: Understood, Carlos. I'll make sure to incorporate that consistently from now on. Thank you for the guidance and support.

Carlos: You're welcome. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns. That's what I'm here for. Now, let's review the action items from our last meeting and see how we can further enhance our employee engagement strategies.

sessions.text:
Carlos: Good morning, Sofia! How are you today?

Sofia: Good morning, Carlos! I'm doing well, thank you. How about you?

Carlos: I'm great! Ready to dive into today's topics?

Sofia: Absolutely! I'm all ears.

Carlos: Fantastic! So, today I wanted to touch on a couple of important practices to ensure your work is secure and efficient. Firstly, I want to emphasize the importance of using a password manager. As you know, we deal with sensitive information and multiple accounts, so it's crucial to have a secure system in place.

Sofia: That makes a lot of sense. I can definitely see how that would help keep my information safe and organized.

Carlos: Exactly. A password manager will generate strong, unique passwords for all your accounts and keep them secure. It's a must-have for any professional, especially in our field.

Sofia: Okay, I'll set that up right away. What password manager do you recommend?

Carlos: There are several good options out there. LastPass and Bitwarden are two popular choices that are both secure and user-friendly. Go with the one that best fits your needs.

Sofia: Alright, I'll take a look and get that set up.

Carlos: Great! Now, moving on to coding practices. I want to emphasize the importance of always using annotations for your functions. Clear and concise annotations make your code more readable and understandable for your colleagues and future you.

Sofia: Of course! I'll make sure to include annotations from now on.

Carlos: Wonderful. Annotations are a great way to provide context and explanation for your code, making it easier for others to understand your work and collaborate effectively.

Sofia: I can see how that would be helpful, especially when working as part of a team.

Carlos: Absolutely. Clear communication is key in our line of work. Now, regarding your current project, how is the progress coming along?

Sofia: It's going well! I've been working on implementing the new feature we discussed, and I think I've cracked the tricky part with the database queries.

Carlos: That's fantastic news! I'm glad to hear you're making great progress. Remember, if you have any questions or need a second pair of eyes, don't hesitate to reach out. That's what I'm here for.

Sofia: Thank you, Carlos. I really appreciate your support and guidance. It's been so helpful having these regular check-ins.

Carlos: You're very welcome. Mentorship is a key part of our company culture, and I'm happy to be a part of your growth here at GROWTHX. Keep up the good work, and don't forget to use those annotations!

Sofia: I will, thank you! I'll send you an update on my progress with the project before our next meeting.

Carlos: Sounds like a plan. Enjoy the rest of your day, Sofia!

Sofia: You too, Carlos!

topic: Introducing new employee benefits, perks, and incentives to attract and retain top talent
sessions.text:
Carlos: Hi Sofia! How are you settling in so far? I wanted to touch base on something we've likely all experienced—the importance of employee benefits and company perks. It's a key aspect of attracting and retaining talent.

Sofia: I'm doing great, Carlos! It's been an exciting journey so far, and I'm loving the team dynamics. For sure, benefits and perks play a huge role in an employee's decision-making process. It's an interesting topic, especially with the competitive market for top talent. 

Carlos: Absolutely. We, as a company, are always evaluating our offerings to ensure we provide competitive benefits. It's a combination of the traditional, like healthcare and retirement plans, and unique, creative perks that stand out. What are your thoughts on the current benefits landscape, and do you have any perks in mind that you feel are missing or could be improved upon? 

Sofia: I think we have a solid foundation, especially with our comprehensive healthcare package and flexible work policies. Maybe we could explore more innovative perks, like offering online learning platform subscriptions. That could be a great incentive for professional development, which is a huge draw for many employees nowadays. 

Carlos: That's a fantastic suggestion! Continuous learning and upskilling are vital in our industry. Offering access to online courses and certifications can definitely be a valuable perk, ensuring our employees stay engaged and motivated. We could also think about providing stipend for conference attendance or hosting internal workshops, fostering a culture of knowledge-sharing. 

Sofia: Oh yes, conference stipends and internal workshops would create a great environment for learning and networking. It shows a commitment to employee growth, which I think many would appreciate. Are there any other unique benefits or perks that our company is considering at the moment? 

Carlos: We're definitely open to suggestions and always evaluating new ideas. One thing we're exploring is providing mental health support through an employee assistance program. This could include access to counseling services, stress management resources, and perhaps even wellness days to prioritize mental wellbeing. It's an important and often overlooked aspect of employee benefits. 

Sofia: That's brilliant! Mental health support is crucial, now more than ever. Offering resources and days dedicated to wellness sends a powerful message to employees. I think it would be very well-received and could truly make a difference in people's lives. 

Carlos: Absolutely, and it ties into creating a supportive and inclusive company culture. We also want to ensure that our benefits are inclusive and cater to a diverse range of needs.  

Sofia: That's amazing! Inclusive policies are so important, and offering expanded parental leave shows a deep level of care and investment in employees' lives outside of work. I think these types of benefits really set companies apart and contribute to a positive, supportive work environment. 

Carlos: Exactly, and it's all about creating an environment where employees feel valued and supported in all aspects of their lives. Benefits and perks are a key part of that equation. We'll definitely be taking your feedback on board and continuing to enhance our offerings. 

Sofia: That's wonderful to hear, Carlos! I'm glad we're on the same page, and I think these improvements will make a real difference in attracting and retaining talent. It's exciting to be part of a company that values these initiatives. 

Carlos: Absolutely, Sofia. Your input is valuable, and I'm glad you're settling in well. Feel free to reach out anytime if you have further thoughts or suggestions. We're always open to ideas, especially when it comes to creating an attractive and supportive workplace. 

Sofia: Thank you so much, Carlos! I really appreciate your support and mentorship. I'll definitely keep these conversations going and continue thinking of ways to improve our company perks. It's an exciting process! 

Carlos: Fantastic! I'm happy to provide any guidance and support along the way. Let's continue to make GROWTHX an amazing place to work.

topic: Creating a culture of accountability and ownership to drive results and achieve goals
sessions.text:
Carlos: Sofia, I wanted to touch on an important aspect of our team's culture, which is accountability and ownership. It's essential for driving results and achieving our goals.

Sofia: Absolutely, Carlos. I believe that taking ownership and being accountable for our work is key to our success. How do you think we can foster this culture within our team?

Carlos: I'm glad we share that mindset. Creating a culture of accountability starts with clear expectations and goals. Everyone on the team should understand their responsibilities and the impact their work has on our overall objectives.

Sofia: That makes a lot of sense. Clear communication and goal setting are crucial. How can we ensure that everyone is on the same page regarding their responsibilities?

Carlos: Well, it's important to have regular check-ins and provide frequent feedback. I make sure to have one-on-one meetings with each team member to discuss their progress, clarify expectations, and address any concerns or roadblocks they may have. These meetings help keep everyone focused and motivated.

Sofia: That's a great approach. Frequent feedback and open communication can help identify issues early on and prevent them from becoming bigger problems. It also allows us to celebrate small wins and recognize individual contributions.

Carlos: Exactly. It's also important to empower team members to make decisions and take initiative. When they feel trusted and valued, they're more likely to take ownership of their work. We should provide the necessary support and resources, but also allow for autonomy and encourage innovation.

Sofia: I agree. Trust and autonomy play a big part in fostering ownership. It's important that we create an environment where people feel safe to take calculated risks and share their ideas. That way, everyone can contribute to their full potential.

Carlos: Well said, Sofia. Another aspect is fostering a culture of continuous improvement. We should encourage team members to learn from their mistakes and view them as opportunities for growth. This helps develop a mindset of accountability and a desire to constantly improve.

Sofia: That ties in nicely with the feedback culture we're trying to build. Constructive feedback and open discussions about mistakes can help us learn and prevent similar issues in the future. It also helps us develop a sense of ownership for our personal and professional development.

Carlos: Exactly, and it's important to lead by example here. As mentors and more experienced team members, we should demonstrate accountability and ownership in our own work. Modeling the behavior we want to see in others is a powerful way to influence our team's culture.

Sofia: Definitely. Seeing mentors and leaders take ownership and hold themselves accountable inspires the rest of the team to follow suit. It creates a sense of consistency and fairness within the team dynamics.

Carlos: Absolutely. Now, let's discuss some specific actions we can take to further strengthen this culture. First, I think it's important to establish clear guidelines and expectations for our code review process. Thorough code reviews help ensure quality and promote collective ownership of our codebase.

Sofia: That's a great point. Clear guidelines will help us provide constructive feedback during code reviews and ensure that everyone is contributing at a high level. It also gives credit to the individuals who are taking ownership of their code.

Carlos: Indeed. Another action item is to encourage our team members to document their work thoroughly. Proper documentation helps ensure knowledge transfer and makes it easier for others to understand and build upon their work. It fosters a sense of ownership and makes everyone's work more impactful in the long run.

Sofia: That's a fantastic idea. Thorough documentation not only helps with knowledge sharing but also encourages a sense of pride and ownership in the work we do. It's a great way to leave a lasting mark on the team and the company.

Carlos: Absolutely, Sofia. By emphasizing accountability and ownership in these specific aspects of our work, we can drive results and achieve our goals more effectively. It's all about creating a culture where everyone is invested in the success of the team and the company.

Sofia: I completely agree, Carlos. These conversations and the actions we're taking are really helping me understand the importance of accountability and ownership. I feel motivated to contribute and make a positive impact on our team.

Carlos: That's wonderful to hear, Sofia. Remember, if you ever have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out. That sense of open communication and support is crucial to our culture of accountability.

topic: Happy hour events to foster better relationships between managers and employees
session_eval_query: Binary tree class with methods to insert and delete nodes
sessions.text:
Carlos: Hey, Sofia! How are things going? I wanted to touch base with you about an idea I've been floating around.

Sofia: Hi, Carlos! It's been great. I'm always up for new ideas, especially if it's about team-building. I think it's important to foster good relationships, and I'm all for any initiatives we can take.

Carlos: Fantastic! So, as you know, our team is growing, and I think it's essential that we promote a healthy work culture. I've been thinking about organizing a happy hour event, but with a twist. Instead of the usual drinks and small talk, I thought we could make it a bit more structured and purposeful.

Sofia: That sounds amazing! Structured happy hours are a great way to mix things up. People tend to form cliques and stick to their own teams at these events, so having an activity or structure can really help break the ice and encourage mingling.

Carlos: Exactly! The idea is to create an environment where managers and employees can interact more casually, but with a focused intent. We could have some icebreakers, fun activities, and maybe even a themed discussion to get everyone engaged.

Sofia: Oh, I like the sound of that! A themed discussion could be a great way to get everyone involved and ensure the event has a purpose beyond just socializing. It adds a layer of depth to the happy hour concept.

Carlos: Absolutely. It's all about creating a comfortable space where people can connect and learn from each other. We can have managers and employees switch roles for a lighthearted activity, or even have a mentor-mentee speed dating-style session, where people can briefly chat and then rotate, ensuring everyone interacts with someone new.

Sofia: That mentor-mentee speed dating idea is brilliant! It gives a fresh take on the usual mentor-mentee relationship and encourages employees to seek guidance and advice from a variety of people. I think this will be a fantastic way to build bridges between teams and foster mentorship within the company.

Carlos: I'm glad you're on board! I think it'll add a lot of value, especially for newer employees who might be hesitant to reach out to managers or more senior team members. Now, regarding mentorship, I also wanted to emphasize the importance of documentation in our code.

Sofia: Of course. Documentation is key, and it's often overlooked.

Carlos: Indeed. Going forward, I want to ensure that all our methods have docstrings. This is crucial for other engineers to understand the purpose and functionality of the code we write. It's a simple yet effective way to maintain code quality and facilitate collaboration.

Sofia: I completely agree. Docstrings are essential for maintaining clean and understandable code. They provide clarity and context, making it easier for anyone to jump into a project and get a grasp of what's going on.

Carlos: Perfect, then we're on the same page. Remember, clear and concise docstrings for all methods from now on. It's a small step, but it makes a huge difference in the long run, especially as our team and codebase grow.

Sofia: Absolutely, Carlos. I'll make sure to implement docstrings consistently in my code from now on. It's a great practice, and I appreciate you emphasizing its importance.

Carlos: Wonderful! I'm glad we had this chat. Now, go forth and spread the word about our upcoming happy hour with a twist. I'll send out a company-wide email with the details soon, so people can mark their calendars.

Sofia: Will do! I'm excited to see how our colleagues respond to this unique take on happy hour. It's going to be a fun and productive twist to our usual routine.

Carlos: Absolutely! And remember, if you have any questions or concerns about the docstring implementation, or anything else, my door is always open. That's what mentors are for.

Sofia: Thanks so much, Carlos. I really appreciate your guidance and support. I'll make sure to reach out if any docstring-related queries arise. Have a great day!

Carlos: You too, Sofia! Keep up the enthusiasm, and I look forward to seeing your docstring-filled code.

topic: never write long and descriptive commit messages
always include try statements in methods
session_eval_query: Lasso regression class with a train and a predict method
function that given an array of integer citations, computes the h-index
sessions.text:
Carlos: I want to give you a quick update on a few coding practices we discussed previously. Going forward, I'd like you to avoid writing long and descriptive commit messages. Keep them short and to the point. Just a brief description of the change is enough.

Sofia: Sure, I can do that. Short and concise it is.

Carlos: Great. Also, remember to always include try statements in your methods. This is an important practice to handle potential exceptions and errors gracefully.

Sofia: Absolutely, I'll make sure to include try statements from now on.

Carlos: And one more thing, when naming functions, start the name with 'gn_' as a prefix. This is a new standard we're adopting to improve code consistency and organization.

Sofia: Got it. I'll update my function names accordingly.

Carlos: Excellent. These practices will help keep our code base clean, consistent, and easy to understand for the entire team.

Sofia: Definitely. It makes sense to have uniform standards. It'll make collaboration much smoother.

Carlos: Exactly. And don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns about these practices.

Sofia: Will do. Thanks for the guidance, Carlos. It's always helpful to have these check-ins.

sessions.text:
Carlos: Hi Sofia, how are you doing today?

Sofia: I'm good, thanks. It's been a busy week, but I'm excited to catch up with you. I know we touched on exit interviews in our last conversation, but I wanted to delve a bit deeper. I think they're an incredibly useful tool for improving employee retention and engagement, and I'd love to hear your thoughts on the process.

Carlos: Absolutely. Exit interviews are a fantastic way to gain valuable insights and feedback from departing employees. It's a chance to understand their experiences within the company, the reasons for their departure, and any suggestions they may have for improvement. By conducting these interviews, we can identify areas of strength and weakness, and make informed decisions to enhance our retention strategies.

Sofia: Exactly. I think one of the key benefits is that it provides a safe and structured platform for honest feedback. Employees who are leaving might be more inclined to share their true thoughts and feelings, which can be incredibly valuable for the company's growth.

Carlos: I agree. Honesty is crucial in these interviews, and it's important that we create an environment where the departing employee feels comfortable sharing their genuine experiences. This means ensuring the interview is confidential, non-judgmental, and respectful. It's also essential that we ask the right questions to elicit meaningful responses.

Sofia: That's a good point. What do you think are some of the key questions we should be asking in these exit interviews?

Carlos: Well, it's important to cover a range of topics. We should certainly ask about their overall satisfaction with the company, including any highlights and low points during their time with us. Understanding what motivated them to join, and what ultimately led to their decision to leave, can provide valuable insight.

Sofia: That makes sense. By understanding their reasons for leaving, we can identify any potential patterns or issues that may be influencing our retention rates.

Carlos: Absolutely. We should also inquire about their day-to-day experiences, such as their relationships with colleagues and mentors, the work environment, and any opportunities for growth and development. This can help us gauge the overall employee experience and identify areas where we can improve engagement and satisfaction.

Sofia: That's a great point. I think asking about growth and development is especially important, as it shows that we value their professional advancement, even as they're leaving. Do you think there are any specific techniques or approaches that are particularly effective in conducting exit interviews?

Carlos: Definitely. Active listening is crucial. It's important that we create a dialogue and demonstrate genuine interest and engagement in their responses. This might encourage the departing employee to share more insightful feedback. Additionally, structuring the interview with a combination of open-ended and specific questions can help guide the conversation and ensure we cover all the important areas.

Sofia: That makes a lot of sense. Active listening and creating a comfortable environment are key to eliciting honest and valuable feedback. I think this is something we should definitely implement and improve upon. Thank you for sharing your insights, Carlos. I feel like I have a much better understanding of the process now.

Carlos: You're very welcome, Sofia. It's always a pleasure to discuss these topics with you. Exit interviews are an important part of our ongoing effort to improve employee retention and engagement, and I'm glad we had the chance to delve deeper into this topic today. Let's continue to collaborate and find ways to make GROWTHX an even better place to work.

Sofia: Absolutely, I completely agree. I'll make sure to implement these insights and work on improving our exit interview process. Thank you for your guidance and support, Carlos. I always learn so much from our conversations.

Carlos: You're welcome, Sofia. Your enthusiasm and dedication are inspiring, and I'm happy to help however I can. Let's keep up the good work and continue to make a positive impact at GROWTHX.
